description: From Middle English infusen, from Latin infusus, from infundo.

verbs.description: infuse (third-person singular simple present infuses, present participle infusing, simple past and past participle infused)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to become an element of something; to insert or fill.
(transitive) To steep in a liquid, so as to extract the soluble constituents (usually medicinal or herbal).
examples: One scruple of the dried leaves is infused in ten ounces of warm water.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To inspire; to inspirit or animate; to fill (with).

examples: Why should he desire to have qualities infused into his son, which himself never possessed, or knew, or found the want of, in the acquisition of his wealth?
Let it infuse for five minutes.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make an infusion with (an ingredient); to tincture; to saturate.
(transitive, obsolete) To pour in, as a liquid; to pour (into or upon); to shed.
examples: That strong Circean liquor cease tâ€™infuse.
